I can reproduce this. It should show the `player` field. (there is no scroll here)

rename.from: Complete is broken for query and resource
rename.to: rust-analyzer autocomplete is broken for some ECS types

body: That's a very odd place for the bisection to lead us ðŸ¤” Are we sure this wasn't caused by a change in RA instead?

What is RAï¼Ÿ
If you mean rust-analyzer, I have tried the version from Aug. to the least release, however, the issue remains.
Yeah, rust-analyzer. Hmm, that's very unusual. Can you double check the bisection? Maybe a PR just before or after is causing the problem. Or try reverting that commit.
I have already tried the commit just before, which works fine. I will check it again when I'm free

I have tried
1. 73a66d6bd8e3d21b928f2a31f1aff5c9fb95a564

```
git check out 73a66d6bd8e3d21b928f2a31f1aff5c9fb95a564
```

2. 760d0a3
```
git checkout main
git revert 760d0a3
```
both works fine with
```
rust-analyzer --version
rust-analyzer 1.83.0 (90b35a6 2024-11-26)
```

I tracked this down to `bevy_ecs_path`.

```diff
  pub(crate) fn bevy_ecs_path() -> syn::Path {
-     BevyManifest::default().get_path("bevy_ecs")
+     BevyManifest::shared().get_path("bevy_ecs")
  }
```

The difference seems to be that before 760d0a31003c70ed6017b2a70059a76d9b268425, this function returned `bevy_internal::ecs`, and now it returns `bevy_ecs`.
We need to make sure that this problem doesn't affect other crates as well.
maybe a bug in how rust-analyser share context between executions? `BevyManifest` is now behind a `LazyLock` which is not an issue in normal compilation, but it seems RA keeps it across crates

issue.title: Autocomplete seems broken by a `LazyLock` + conditional crate paths

repository.name: rust-analyzer
repository.description: A Rust compiler front-end for IDEs

body:
> maybe a bug in how rust-analyser share context between executions? `BevyManifest` is now behind a `LazyLock` which is not an issue in normal compilation, but it seems RA keeps it across crates

Seems like the most likely cause.

For now it may be best to just revert the commit.

Sorry for the breakage. ðŸ˜…

Based on the discussion in the linked issue, reverting the PR sounds like the best option. I'd like to ask though, would reverting the PR bring us back into a state of not relying on external state within the proc macro? If not, maybe more thought should go into a solution.

It would not. However there is a nightly feature for tracked path and tracked environment variables in nightly that should guarantee the external state dependence.

I actually went ahead and iterated upon BevyManifest for my own monorepo project.

https://github.com/ink-feather-org/cargo-manifest-proc-macros-rs

I will make my bevy fork depend on it and see if that solves the RA and external state issues.

I have thought about it quite a bit by now. RA seems to keep the proc macros server running and only alters the environment variables. This I did not account for. It should be possible to do a workaround in stable rust by using a HashMap of LazyLocked BevyManifests to look up which crate RA invoked the proc macros for. But to justify this added complexity build performance should be benchmarked.

> maybe a bug in how rust-analyser share context between executions? `BevyManifest` is now behind a `LazyLock` which is not an issue in normal compilation, but it seems RA keeps it across crates

I wouldn't call it a bug. rust-analyzer caches proc-macro expansions keyed by their invocation inputs, unlike rustc (which is currently experimenting with caching derives fwiw). proc-macros generally shouldn't rely on global state like this as even rustc doesn't make a guarantee about the order or frequency of proc-macro invocations.

> However there is a nightly feature for tracked path and tracked environment variables in nightly that should guarantee the external state dependence.

Those are not implemented in rust-analyzer yet.

> I have thought about it quite a bit by now. RA seems to keep the proc macros server running and only alters the environment variables. 

Yes, we keep the proc-macro library loaded (so `static`s do not get reset), we do spawn a new thread per expansion though (so thread locals do get reset). So an easy fix here would be to use a thread local instead of a `static`, though the better fix really would be to not cache anything inside globals in the first place.
